Chlorine/Sulfur Dioxide



The Sparks facility framework for the accidental release prevention program includes a commitment to process safety, an understanding of hazards and risk, management of risk and learning from experience as well as compliance with regulatory requirements.  The plant has a Process Safety Management system for Chlorine as defined by OSHA (Federal and State) including the elements:  process safety information; process hazard analysis; operating procedures; training; mechanical integrity; management of change; pre-startup safety review; compliance audits; incident investigations; employee participation; hot work permit; and contractor management.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Sierra Chemical Company, a Carus Group Inc. is a leader in the water purification chemical industry.   At Carus Group Inc. we manufacture quality products to help our customers solve environmental concerns and our vision reflects a long-term commitment to serve our customers. Carus supports the American Chemistry Council's Responsible Care, an initiative that fosters involvement in the community and continuous improvement in environmental, health, security, and safety performance.  Sierra Chemical Company is a member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors and has been certified to be in compliance with the Responsible Distribution Code. The company is also an active member of the Chlorine Institute, a trade group that develops and establishes recommended practices for the safe handling of chlorine.



The Sierra Chemical Company, Sparks plant is a chemical manufacturer, packager and distributor of industrial chemicals. The markets for the Sparks plant include water treatment, wastewater treatment, industrial applications, agriculture, and food processing. Chlorine is packaged and distributed for the water treatment, wastewater treatment, and industrial markets.

 

Carus Corporation's President and CEO states in their EHSS Charter that the Environmental, Health, Safety, and Security Mission  is to achieve a manufacturing environment that we are proud of  by continuously improving our ability to provide  our customers  with quality products and services that meet their needs while operating with the highest standards of safety and environmental compliance. To operate with the highest standards of safety and environmental compliance our commitment to EHSS must include: compliance with work instructions and procedures; clear expectations; a constant focus on prevention; active participation; awareness on and off the job; strong leadership; and personal responsibility.  



Further, a commitment to EHSS must include personal accountability for their EHSS p

erformance and for the EHSS performance of those they manage or supervise.  A commitment on the part of all employees and contractors is crucial to achieving the EHSS mission. Compliance with all expectations set forth in the EHSS Charter will help develop the EHSS culture and ensure Carus operates with the highest standards of safety and environmental awareness. These expectations are a key part of job performance assessments. Carus will not tolerate failure to live up to the expectations outlined in this charter; as such failure could negatively impact the health and safety of our employees, our community, and the environment.  The EHSS Charter has been reviewed and endorsed by Sierra Chemical Company, Sparks Plant personnel and plant management demonstrates EHSS leadership and commitment.

In addition to EPA's RMP rule, the Sparks plant complies with State and Federal OSHA's Process Safety Management, EPA's State and Federal Hazardous Waste Generator, DHS Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard and DOT's Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration regulatory requirements.



There are two Worse Case Toxic release scenarios (Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide) and two Alternate Case Chlorine release scenarios (Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide) assessed for the Sparks plant. Section 2 of this RMP submittal contains additional details regarding the Worse Case release scenario while Section 3 contains additional details for the Alternate Case release scenario. 



The Worse Case toxic release scenarios are briefly described and include: (1) chlorine rail car releasing 195,840 pounds with a distance to end point (rural ) of 6 miles. (2) Sulfur Dioxide rail car release 201,280 pounds with a distance to end point (rural) of 6 miles.



The Alternate Case toxic release scenarios are briefly described and include: (1) chlorine process pipe leak releasing 8,096 pounds with a distance to end point (rural) of <3 miles.  (2) Sulfur dioxide rail car release 30,103 pounds with

a distance to end point (rural) of 6 miles.



To ensure a common basis for comparisons, EPA defined the worst-case scenario as the release of the larges1 quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint. The alternative release rate is a release that is considered more reasonable or "more likely." EPA's Cameo (Aloha, marplot, cameo chemical) model used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint which becomes a radius for a circle around the covered process. Residential population within the circle is required to be determined based on available census information; hence, the population number for each scenario is reported as part of this EPA submittal. Since wind direction cannot be anticipated for an accidental release, EPA mandated the circle estimation method. This method greatly over estimates the population potentially exposed to a release since the prominent wind direction and other factors are not taken into account. Generally, the Sparks Plant components for the accidental release prevention program includes a commitment to process safety, an understanding of hazards and risk, management of risk and learning from experience as well as compliance  with regulatory requirements.  The plant has a Process Safety Management (PSM) system for the covered processes as defined by OSHA. The Chlorine includes the following PSM elements process safety information; process hazard analysis; operating procedures; training; mechanical integrity; management of change; pre-startup safety review; compliance audits; incident investigations; employee participation; hot work permit; contractor management; emergency planning and response. 



Throughout the plant, a hierarchy of controls has been implemented including hazard elimination, substitution, engineering controls, administrative controls and personal protective equipment to minimize or eliminate exposure to hazards

Infrastructure security im

provements at designated areas in the plant have been implemented that provide layers of protection against deliberate man-made incidents in accordance with applicable elements of U.S. Department of Homeland Security's CFATS Risk Based Performance Standards.



In the last five years, the Sparks plant has no accidental releases.



The plant has a trained emergency response team comprised of on-site personnel that meets applicable Indiana OSHA and other regulatory requirements. In-plant emergency response team training includes classroom instruction; hands-on demonstrations Each year a plant emergency response team member attend the Mississippi Fire Academy's HAZMAT Response Training.

 

A plant management team representative attends the Chlorine Institute's Annual and Fall Meetings to learn new safety-related developments and best practices involving the safe production, use and distribution of chlorine.

Several changes to improve safety and security are planned, budgeted or being implemented including process controls, mitigation systems, monitoring/detection systems, security physical protection systems, hazard reviews/evaluations, contractor management and additional personnel resources. For example, Carus Corporation has created a position for a PSM Specialist to support plants in their PSM activities such as providing audit assistance, process hazard an analysis lead/facilitator role, regulatory updates, PSM incident analysis and sharing best practices. Also, this individual provides leadership, culture, and policy guidance to Carus Corporation and Sierra Chemical Company management regarding their PSM System.
